name: Pretty Pangrammed Pics Online Quiz | Movie Mixture | 10 Questions

questions.text: The hive of boxing wizards jump quickly.
questions.correct: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
questions.explanation:
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix.

	The pangram here talks specifically about the scene where the Weasley twins start a fight with several other wizards (sure not an actual boxing match) and then jump on their broomsticks to leave Hogwarts castle.  Fred and George Weasley were played in the movies by James and Oliver Phelps.

questions.text: Whiny teens fight quick, morph, use big zords to jolt Divatox.
questions.explanation:
Power Rangers Turbo.

	"Power Rangers Turbo" was the second big screen adaptation of the "Power Rangers" franchise. The five "teenagers with attitude" had their zords upgraded to cars early in the movie when they adopted the new turbo powers. They used those zords to battle and defeat the villain Divatox.  While the movie had nothing to do with the TV series, it did have the same core cast for the Rangers and Divatox.

questions.text: Playing jazz vibe chords quickly excites my wife.
questions.explanation:
The Jazz Singer.

	"The Jazz Singer" (1927) was the first "talkie" film, as in the first film with sound. It starred Al Jolson. It was remade in 1980 with Neil Diamond in the lead role.  The pangram here is a bit on the nose, it refers to the titular character and how the movie deals with his home life.

questions.text: Never lazy, two quick friends with moxy, jump bark and go play.
questions.explanation:
The Fox and the Hound.

	Released by Disney in 1981, "The Fox and the Hound" was the story of a fox, Tod, and a dog, Copper and their friendship. The movie was based on a book by Daniel P. Mannix. The pangram here doesn't refer to a specific scene, but the friendship between the animals as a while.

questions.text: Pack my box with five dozen liquor jugs.
options: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
The Garbage Picking Field Goal Kicking Philadelphia Phenomenon
questions.explanation:
The Mighty Ducks.

	The pangram here refers to the setup of the movie, "The Mighty Ducks".  The movie, which spawned two sequels, follows lawyer Gordan Bombay as he gets a DUI and is sentenced to community service.His law firm tells him to do the community service by coaching a youth hockey team, hence the reference to both a box (penalty box in hockey) and liquor (the character being a drunk). Emilio Estevez had the starring role.

questions.text: Five or six big jet planes zoomed quickly by the tower.
questions.explanation:
Top Gun.

	"Top Gun", starring Tom Cruise is a near perfect fit for this pangram. The movie follows Maverick (Cruise) as he and his partner try to pass the top gun flight school and become among the best of the best. There is actually a scene in the movie where Maverick decided to "buzz" the tower.

questions.text: The vixen jumped quickly on her foe barking with zeal.
questions.explanation:
A Dog's Way Home.

	"A Dog's Way Home" is an inspirational movie about a dog who ran away, but eventually found her way back home after a long journey.  She ended up traveling more than 400 miles over the course of the movie.  The pangram here is metaphorical, as the "distance" was the dog's actual foe, though there was a scene where she had to distract and escape from a wild fox. That scene did include barking and jumping.

Iron Jawed Angels.

	The film, starring Hilary Swank (as Alice Paul) and Frances O'Connor (as Lucy Burns) is set in the early 1900s as they fight for women's rights to vote. The movie follows the two Quaker women as they use every strategy they can think of to peacefully navigate through the women's suffrage movement.  The pangram refers to the entire plot, if more people had sympathized with them, they wouldn't have had to fight for their rights.

questions.text: Exquisite farm wench gives joy, bold support, to prize stinker.
questions.explanation:
Field of Dreams.

	The exquisite farm wench referenced by the pangram is Amy Madigan's Annie, who stood beside her husband (the prize stinker) as he cut down crops on their farm in order to build a baseball field.  The movie followed Ray (Kevin Costner) as he sought something bigger than himself. He kept hearing a voice that told him to do things, and rather than work to fix his family's finances, listened to the voice.  In the end, with the encouragement of his wife, Ray built the baseball stadium and people came from miles around to enjoy what he had built, as well as some more mysterious visitors.

questions.text: A quick movement of the enemy will jeopardize a gunboat, needing a fix.
questions.explanation:
The Sand Pebbles.

	The movie was based on "The Sand Pebbles" novel from Richard McKenna. It was published in 1962, the movie followed in 1966. The movie starred Steve McQueenRichard Attenborough, Richard Crenna and Candice Bergen. The pangram refers to the danger the men on the gunboat were in while they were fighting in the Nationalist Northern Expedition in China.
